text: hi everyone earth any hurt a no here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new weather day
album come in this is the new semi
breakout album from Swedish music
project weather day and I say breakout
because this record has stirred quite
the commotion in the underground music
community mostly within the realms of
lo-fi and bedroom pop and from what I
can tell the buzz is not due to some
celebrity endorsement or a major label
deal it seems pretty organic with many
fans hailing this album as an artistic
feat for DIY whatever Sputnik the
mastermind of weather day is doing it's
really striking a chord they're not
working with an unfamiliar mix of genres
though there is certainly some indie
rock going into this record some noise
pop some emo occasionally all of this is
enhanced with some great background
vocals pianos some samples or even
electronics and the whole recording is
as low Phi as a [ __ ] if you're
the kind of person who might avoid a
Neutral Milk Hotel album or a
microphones or a Mount Erie album
because there are too many noisy lo-fi
bits within it you are not going to have
a fun time with this one think of taking
the incredibly low fidelity of a waves
album in early waves album and then
trying to apply to that the instrumental
ambition of an old Sufjan Stevens record
and while that's not a perfect
comparison it's close in some respects
this album is more abrasive and harsh
than a classic Scandinavian black metal
album I mean those squeaking wailing
lead melodies that top the choruses of
the track cut lips are absolutely ear
piercing not just ear piercing but ear
stabbing
they're most likely giving someone
tinnitus right now who's listening to
this thing way too loud I can't say
Sputnik isn't doing a lot with a little
on this record though they're certainly
very creative with how they choose to
operate within the very limited fidelity
of sound that they work with in the
performances on this thing aren't bad
either sure they are pretty sloppy but
still they are delivered with a lot of
heart a lot of energy certainly all the
chaos of this record is complemented
with the explosive energy it presents
case in point the song older than
or easily some of the most fun
throttling rock music I've heard this
year between the crunchy rhythm guitars
and sparkling arpeggios the distorted
and sandpaper rough drums on this track
to adding all of this together I think
Sputnik shows more guts than most major
label rock releases dropping this year
and again that is despite the low fire
recording that is despite all the
instrumentation sounding so
claustrophobic it's like it's been
squeezed into a drainpipe and I'm not
exactly sure what's causing that
obviously it's intentional but is it
because everything was recorded too
loudly was it all done in post I'm not
sure either way the whole thing sounds
like if you were sitting comfortably in
your living room on the couch but every
other piece of furniture around you was
on fire in that respect come in isn't
too different from the early works of
let's say car seat headrest and even
though I think most of the similarities
between weather day and car C headrest
end with their low fidelity recordings I
have no doubt this album is thriving
because of the demand that projects like
twin fantasy as well as teens of denial
have created not just for rock music
that's low Phi but low Phi rock music
that's also thematic as well as
ambitious and conceptual in some ways
come in as like low Phi's answer to the
rock opera as this record features
10-minute songs melodic reprises as well
as tragic lyrics car seat headrest isn't
the only comparison I'd like to make in
this review though because I'm seeing
other artistic parallels with the likes
of early Conor Oberst whether that be
super super super early bright eyes or
commander Venus
some 90s emo maybe even some more
melodic cuts from the hüsker dü
discography and most certainly Phil
elrom everything Phil elrom I would say
their points on this thing that are
blatant Phil elrom worship like on the
final moments of sleep while doing your
best the droning basins singing on that
track and certainly there are some piano
passages that have that really sharp
ringing pain to them that I remember so
vividly from records like the glow part
2 so truthfully some of the material on
this project if you are familiar with
the worlds of lo-fi and indie
singer-songwriter music can feel a
little derivative or even kind of bland
like on the track water dreamer this
the first leg of which I think could
have used a little something extra it's
not bad but it does feel like the album
is beginning to paint itself into a
corner
the instrumental switch in the second
leg of this track drags on a little bit
- then there's also the very same Ian's
underwhelming first leg of the track
porcelain hands the closer here I do
love that the main theme melody of this
record that pops up also on the intro
comes back for a grand finale but the
washed out vocals and guitars that have
little to no flavor or rather have lost
their flavor by this point on the
project aren't doing any favors for this
thing being the closing track however
the majority of songs on this record if
you can get past the lo-fi production or
even enjoy and appreciate what Sputnik
does with it then and only then I think
you'll find come in to be pretty catchy
anthemic ambitious and emotionally
compelling the first two tracks on this
thing are fantastic a great tone setter
for the record mio mio mio that's where
a lot of the album's lyrical themes and
narrative become very apparent where we
see our protagonists sad over the loss
of a connection they had with this
person that obviously meant very much to
them it's too rare in life to find
someone you love that can stick around
after thunderclouds it's too rare in
life to find someone you love to open up
to sometimes and not regret you did -
and the vocals on this track are
incredibly incredibly distressed in a
way that benefits the song also loving
the crescendo of noise in the first half
of this song the anthemic guitar leads
that lead us there the curious
instrumental shift after the halfway
point and the grand chorus of singers
that kind of coast the song out it's
very lovely and even bigger feet is the
song my Sputnik sweetheart which is a 13
minute epic kicking things off with some
very raw and bittersweet guitar chords
the vocals are way more buried at the
start than I would have liked but once
they get louder they really pop in the
mix then some kind of tragic but also
slightly melodramatic lyrics are
revealed but also learn to eat like
nothing's left who is your influence
losing sense of self in place asking who
I love the way the first leg of this
track builds up into this swaying heart
broken spiral of sadness still on the
same track
and very nicely into some plucky
acoustics and gorgeous vocal harmonies
electric guitars then bring the music to
another punky rush backed with all these
crashing drums then some of the most
unhinged vocals on the entire record
some of the harshest noise on the entire
record and at this point we're only in
the middle of the track there's still
six minutes or so to go each one of them
more thrilling than the last I also love
how embarrassing painting serves as a
very necessary somewhat mellow and woozy
cooled down moment a palate cleanser
that really shows that Sputnik is paying
very close attention to how all of these
tracks flow into each other as long as i
mentioning highlights there's also
agatha you're being dramatic which
features some gorgeous forlorn choral
vocals singing some very high notes over
crunchy guitars more rough sandpaper
drums I really appreciate the change in
instrumental palette this song brings it
once again reminds me of the flow of the
record being so good and how cinematic
it all is in a way overall I found
coming to be very enjoyable while also
flawed in some pretty apparent ways the
influences are a bit too obvious there
are points where I wish the vocals were
a bit more up front or just performed a
bit better and yes of course there are
parts on this album where the harshness
and the low fidelity
I think kneecaps the enjoyability still
though this is easily one of the more
creative rock records I've heard this
year one of the more creative lo-fi and
indie records I've heard this year I
can't claim to be as passionate about it
as some of the biggest disciples of this
project but this certainly has me
looking forward to more I'm feeling a
decent too strong 7 on this one
